required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: The Pathogenesis of Hepatitis C Virus Vertical Transmission
clinical_study.official_title: The Pathogenesis of Hepatitis C Virus Vertical Transmission

lead_sponsor.agency: University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill

clinical_study.source: University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill

brief_summary.textblock:
To evaluate for the presence of HCV Core protein, HCV RNA and SPP in the placenta and fetal membranes using paraffin-embedded sections and post-delivery specimens respectively. In parallel, we will assess placental tissue for evidence of HCV infection using a novel in situ hybridization technique and translate our in vitro findings to these in vivo samples.
Our overall hypothesis is that cytotrophoblasts at the maternal-fetal interface within the placenta serve as a "barrier" that must be crossed during vertical transmission and that cytotrophoblasts are permissive to HCV at a low level that may be enhanced under certain conditions. By comparing the regulation of key steps in the intracellular life cycle of HCV in cytotrophoblasts to highly permissive hepatocytes, significant differences in HCV regulation should be revealed.
Based on our preliminary data, our working hypothesis is that HCV Core protein is differentially processed in cytotrophoblasts compared to hepatocytes.

clinical_study.study_design: Observational Model: Case Control, Time Perspective: Cross-Sectional

primary_outcome.measure: To evaluate for the presence of HCV Core protein, HCV RNA and SPP in the placenta and fetal membranes using paraffin-embedded sections and post-delivery specimens respectively.
primary_outcome.description: We will begin by examining paraffin-embedded sections from HCV-infected mothers who had the placentas sent to pathology for analysis.We will perform a combination of immunohistochemistry (IHC) and immunofluorescence (IF) to analyze the level of SPP expression in the trophoblast cell layer, as well as if HCV Core protein expression was detectable in this layer or in any cell type within the placental section. We would also plan to identify other patient-derived tissues that were not paraffin embedded, both from uninfected patients and infected patients to validate different parts of our preliminary data. We would plan to use dissected fetal membranes, which contain both chorion and amnion, to investigate the level of SPP expression in these tissues.

biospec_descr.textblock: Our planned protocol will be to secure whole placental organs after delivery for study patients. Tissue preparation will include a combination of segments preserved in nucleic acid preservative (TriZol or equivalent) and flash freeze of sections to preserve cellular anatomy.

study_pop.textblock: Pregnant women with HCV infection who present to our collaborating institution in Egypt, and at UNC

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Pregnant women with HCV infection
- Pregnant women without HCV infection
Exclusion Criteria:
- None

overall_official.affiliation: UNC Department of Pediatrics: Division of Allergy, Immunology, Rheumatology and Infectious Diseases

facility.name: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill

responsible_party.investigator_affiliation: University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill
